## Quick answer in plain language  

*If you stand 2‑5 m (6‑15 ft) from a typical 5G **small‑cell** antenna (the low‑power “mini‑tower” that is often mounted on a street‑light or building façade), the average radio‑frequency (RF) exposure you receive is **orders of magnitude lower** than the limits that national and international health‑safety bodies have set for the general public. In most real‑world measurements the exposure is comparable to—or even lower than—the background exposure you get from everyday sources such as Wi‑Fi routers, Bluetooth devices, and the cellular phone you are holding.*

## 2. What “typical exposure” means for a small‑cell antenna  

### 2.1  Key technical parameters that determine exposure  

| Parameter | Typical value for a 5G small‑cell (sub‑6 GHz) | Typical value for a 5G small‑cell (mmWave, e.g., 28 GHz) |
|-----------|----------------------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------|
| **Maximum transmit power (EIRP)** – the power that would be measured if the antenna radiated equally in all directions | **0.5 W – 5 W** (≈ 27 dBm – 37 dBm)  | **0.1 W – 1 W** (≈ 20 dBm – 30 dBm) |
| **Antenna gain** (how much the beam is focused) | 10 – 15 dBi (≈ 10‑30 × more power in the main beam) | 20 – 30 dBi (≈ 100‑1000 × more power in the main beam) |
| **Resulting **Effective Isotropic Radiated Power (EIRP)** (power × gain) | 5 W – 50 W (≈ 37 dBm – 47 dBm) | 10 W – 100 W (≈ 40 dBm – 50 dBm) |
| **Typical duty cycle for a given beam** (fraction of time the antenna actually points at you) | **< 10 %** (often < 1 % for a single user) | **< 5 %** (bursts of a few µs, repeated at ≤ 1 kHz) |
| **Distance considered “a few metres”** | 2 m, 3 m, 5 m | Same distances (the same geometric spreading applies) |

> **Why duty‑cycle matters** – The *peak* power in the main beam can be a few watts, but because the beam is swept only when a phone is actively communicating, the *average* power that reaches a static observer is the peak power multiplied by the duty cycle, often reducing the average by a factor of 10–100.
